perturbation.original_text: 10.6 Insurance. Each Party shall maintain, at its own cost, comprehensive product liability insurance, general commercial liability insurance and business interruption insurance at a level which is reasonable and customary taking into account the nature of the Product but which shall have combined limits of not less than $[**] per occurrence. Such insurance shall be with a reputable insurance company and where reasonably possible (taking into account the availability of such insurance) shall be maintained for not less than [**] ([**]) years following the expiry or termination of this Agreement. During the Term, neither Party shall do or omit to do any act, matter or thing which could prejudice or render voidable any such insurance. Each Party will provide to the other Party evidence of its insurance and thirty (30) days prior written notice of any cancellation of its coverage or reduction in coverage from the requirements stated herein.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.6 Insurance. Each Party may maintain product liability insurance. During the Term, neither Party shall do or omit to do any act, matter or thing which could prejudice or render voidable any such insurance. Each Party may provide to the other Party evidence of its insurance at their discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of the comprehensive insurance requirement and the specific liability limits introduces legal risk.  Businesses in California are generally expected to maintain adequate insurance coverage based on their operations and potential liabilities. Omitting the 'comprehensive' aspect and 'minimum coverage' implies the party could choose minimal or no coverage, increasing risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Insurance Code and general principles of business liability.
